In this way, in all these worlds, all the Buddhas are taken refuge in, and the great assembly of Bodhisattva-Mahasattvas are also all taken refuge in.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Are the lifespans of all these TathÄgata Buddhas equal or not?
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Listen carefully!
I will explain it for you.
Bhiká¹£us!
One kalpa in my SahÄ world, the Buddha ÅšÄkyamuni's country, is one day and night in the Land of Bliss.
One eon in the land of AmitÄbha Buddha in the world of peace and happiness is one day and night in the land of Vajra-shattering Buddha in the world of KÄá¹£Äya-dhvaja.
One eon in the world of KÄá¹£Äya-dhvaja is one day and night in the land of Saá¹ƒkusumita-abhijÄti-rÄja TathÄgata Buddha in the world of Avinivartanacakra-rÅ«ta, the land of good and excellent light.

Bhiká¹£us!
Entering such a number, after ten asaá¹ƒkhyeya hundreds of thousands of myriads of worlds, in the last world of PadmaÅ›rÄ«, in the Buddha land of the TathÄgata BhadraÅ›rÄ«, it is one day and night.
Bhiká¹£us!
Such worlds are immeasurable and boundless, with different lengths. The lifespans of the buddhas and tathÄgatas abiding in the world are also like this.ğŸ”½Bhiká¹£us!
Bhiká¹£us!
You should all chant the names of the buddhas. In the original text from India, the names of the worlds are given after this, but they are omitted here. Say the following:

I take refuge in such innumerable and boundless great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas in the worlds of the ten directions.
I respectfully pay homage to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all the sages.

Homage to the Venerable Fulfilled Wishes, Homage to the Venerable Free from Obstructions, Homage to the Venerable Flowing Water, Homage to the Venerable Firmly Subdued, Homage to the Venerable Face King, Homage to the Venerable Different Coming, Homage to the Venerable Kind Nature, Homage to the Venerable Auspicious Joy, Homage to the Venerable Well Come, Homage to the Venerable Rahula - I take refuge in such well-known great arhats.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I will next repent.
Disciples!
Having already repented all the retributions, I will now once again repent all offenses in a general way, earnestly requesting the Buddhas of the ten directions to protect and guard the disciples.

From beginningless and immeasurable hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of kalpas until now, we have created evil karma that cannot be fully described. We may have committed the ten evil deeds, the five heinous crimes, and slandered the Vaipulya sÅ«tras, or created immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya offenses. Now we take refuge in the buddhas of the ten directions, take refuge in the Dharma of the ten directions, and take refuge in the Saá¹…gha of the ten directions.

Next, we again take refuge and bow to Aká¹£obhya Buddha in the east, Ratnasaá¹ƒbhava Buddha in the south, AmitÄbha Buddha in the west, Amoghasiddhi Buddha in the north, Gandhottama KÅ«á¹­a Buddha above, and ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha below.

We bow to Samantabhadra Bodhisattva in the east, Dhá¹›á¸ha Bodhisattva in the south, AvalokiteÅ›vara Bodhisattva in the west, Candraprabha Bodhisattva in the north, Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha Bodhisattva above, and VajraÅ›iras Bodhisattva below, to our original teacher ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha, and take refuge in the future Buddha-nature.
We also bow to the transformed buddhas and bodhisattvas in other directions, such as VimalakÄ«rti and MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«.
I also pay homage to Ä€nanda, KÄÅ›yapa, and the four noble paths that appear.

I also take refuge in those who have begun to receive the teachings, and bow to the great canon, the twelve divisions of the scriptures, and the eight-part relics and images of the other scriptures, the Vaipulya true canon.

I also take refuge in those who currently perform buddha-works, the four heavenly kings, Åšakra DevÄnÄm Indra of the TrÄyastriá¹ƒÅ›a Heaven, the thirty-three heavens, the heavens in space, above the ground, and below the ground, and all the sages in the mountains, forests, and under the trees.
Those with great spiritual powers, those with the heavenly eye, and those with the heavenly ear, I pray that they will grant their hearing and knowledge to bear witness to all.
I pray that all sentient beings, those who have not yet repented, will attain the eradication of their offenses upon repenting.
Disciples!
Today, in repentance, I bare my heart and reveal my innermost thoughts. I take refuge in the Buddha with utmost sincerity.

Homage to the Buddha of Immovable Wisdom in the East, Homage to the Buddha of Sun and Moon Lamp Light in the South, Homage to the Buddha of Supreme Excellence in the West, Homage to the Buddha of Inner Abundance and Strict Adornments in the North, Homage to the Buddha of Accomplishment in the Southeast, Homage to the Buddha of Jewel Illuminating the Void in the Southwest, Homage to the Buddha of Seeing Without Fear in the Northwest, Homage to the Buddha of Lion's Power in the Northeast, Homage to the Buddha of Cutting Off Doubt, Pulling Out Desire, and Removing Darkness in the Nadir, Homage to the Buddha of Golden Jewel Light in the Zenith. I take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout the realm of space, like this.
Disciples!

Since beginningless world systems up to now, in this evil body, confused and deluded, with immeasurable inverted views, afflictions, and evil karma, I cannot fully describe them. The many offenses I commit, I am not aware of. With an evil mind, I do not see the afterlife.

But they only see the present happiness of cultivating afflictions and being far from the roots of goodness, obstructed by evil karma and close to bad friends, or committing illegalities in the presence of bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, parents, or the great assembly.

Or, they may have used the wealth of the Saá¹…gha at will, or have made right and wrong distinctions among the five parts of the Saá¹…gha, or have spoken of immeasurable evil fruits in the world, or have killed beings with the roots of goodness of bodhi, or have slandered Dharma teachers, speaking of Dharma as non-Dharma and non-Dharma as Dharma.
Namely, saying the TathÄgata is impermanent, the true Dharma is impermanent, and the Saá¹…gha Jewel is impermanent, not delighting in giving, and believing in false teachings.

Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Therefore, today we have immeasurable fears and immeasurable shame. We take refuge in the Three Jewels, the compassionate Buddhas, the parents of the Vaipulya sÅ«tras, and the friends and teachers of the bodhisattvas. We allow them to reveal and repent for us today.
Disciples!

Since beginningless eons, we have committed the five heinous crimes, violated the precepts of the Buddhas of the past, present, and future, engaged in the conduct of icchantikas, uttered coarse words to slander the true Dharma, and created these grave karmic offenses without ever repenting or feeling ashamed.

We may have committed the ten evil deeds and other offenses, knowingly committing such grave matters, with no initial fear or shame in our hearts. We have silently accepted offerings without ever revealing ourselves, and have no intention of protecting, cherishing, or establishing the true Dharma. In the meantime, we have disparaged and belittled it, speaking of its many faults.
We may have said that there is no Buddha, Dharma, or Sangha, or may have not believed in the existence of the hells and the retribution for our actions.

Offenses such as these are immeasurable and boundless. Today, with immeasurable fear and immeasurable shame, we take refuge in the Three Jewels, the compassionate Buddhas, the parents of the Vaipulya [Dharma], and the spiritual friends and teachers, and request their permission to confess and repent.
Disciples!

From immeasurable eons ago up to the present day, we have had views of the four inversions and have said that the four grave offenses are sthÅ«lÄtyaya offenses, and sthÅ«lÄtyaya offenses are the four grave offenses. We have said that violations are non-violations and non-violations are violations, and that light offenses are grave and grave offenses are light. We have had pure views of impurity and impure views of purity.

Or we have had wrong views, praising worldly texts and not respecting the Buddha's scriptures. We have engaged in all kinds of evil debates and kept the eight impure things. We have taken the Buddha's true words to be MÄra's words and MÄra's words to be the Buddha's words.
Or we have believed and accepted what the six non-Buddhist teachers have said, or we have said:
The TathÄgata has now returned to nirvÄá¹‡a, and the Three Jewels are impermanent.
We have given rise to immeasurable inverted views with our bodies and minds.

Therefore, today we have immeasurable fears and immeasurable shame. We take refuge in the Three Jewels, the Buddhas' compassion, the parents of the vaipulya sÅ«tras, and the friends and teachers of the bodhisattvas. We request that they allow us to confess our transgressions and repent.

May the disciples, by the merit generated from repenting like this, wish to rescue all sentient beings in the ten directions, lifetime after lifetime, to be free from the ten evil deeds and cultivate the ten wholesome deeds, to relieve all suffering and attain peace, and to enable the inconceivable asaá¹ƒkhyeya sentient beings to abide in the ten grounds.
All wholesome dharmas in this land and other worlds are dedicated.

The wholesome deeds of body, speech, and mind that I cultivate, I wish to realize the unsurpassed path in the future. May all women become men, endowed with wisdom, diligent and persevering, all practicing the bodhisattva path, and diligently cultivating the six pÄramitÄs.
If in this JambudvÄ«pa and other worlds, the various kinds of excellent merits created by sentient beings, I now deeply rejoice in them with my mind.

I now rejoice in this merit and the good deeds I have done with body, speech, and mind. I wish to attain supreme enlightenment in the future, to obtain the pure, immaculate, auspicious karmic retribution, and to fully possess the perfect enlightenment of the TathÄgata.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of the Åšramaá¹‡a Precious Arrival of the Lotus in the MahÄyÄna, on Karmic Retribution Precious Arrival then entered the Hell of Burning Bodies.
What is meant by the Hell of Burning Bodies?

The hell was fifty yojanas long and wide, surrounded by iron walls, with raging flames burning the sinners. The bodies of the sinners were also burning, with smoke and fire coming out from their pores.
In the east gate, there were eight hundred sinners who entered and cried out loudly, beating their whole bodies:
What sin have I committed to come in here?

The horse-headed rÄká¹£asa grabbed a three-pronged iron pitchfork, thrust it into their backs, and it came out through their chests. As they entered the ground, there was fire burning, and fire also burned in their bodies. From the six sense faculties, fire flowed out. For a day and a night, they experienced immeasurable suffering, unable to live or die.
Baota asked the horse-headed rÄká¹£asa:
What sins did these monks commit to suffer such torment?
The rÄká¹£asa replied:
These monks, either as teachers or disciples, did not follow each other. The teacher was not kind to the disciples, and the disciples did not respect the teacher.
They each became angry with each other, shouting loudly, glaring and arguing, eventually giving rise to resentment, and fell into this hell.
After leaving hell, they will meet each other in life after life, constantly killing each other.
